gkwreg 1.1.3
  • Reference

    Predict Method for gkwfit Objects

    predict.gkwfit.Rd

    Computes various types of predictions based on a model fitted by the gkwfit function. This includes predicted density (pdf), cumulative probability (CDF), quantiles, or the theoretical mean response of the fitted distribution.

    # S3 method for class 'gkwfit'
predict(
  object,
  newdata = NULL,
  type = c("density", "cdf", "quantile", "response"),
  p = NULL,
  ...
)

    Arguments

    object

    An object of class "gkwfit", typically the result of a call to gkwfit.

    newdata

    An optional numeric vector of values strictly between 0 and 1 at which to compute predictions for type = "density" or type = "cdf". If NULL (the default) for these types, an error is raised as specific points are required. For type = "response", if newdata is provided, the calculated mean is replicated to match the length of newdata; otherwise (if newdata = NULL), a single mean value is returned. For type = "quantile", this argument is ignored.

    type

    A character string specifying the type of prediction required. Valid options are:

    • "density": Computes the probability density function (pdf) values. Requires the newdata argument.

    • "cdf": Computes the cumulative distribution function (CDF) values. Requires the newdata argument.

    • "quantile": Computes the quantiles for given probabilities. Requires the p argument. Ignores newdata.

    • "response": Computes the theoretical mean of the fitted distribution. Does not strictly require newdata, but if provided, the result is replicated to match its length.

    p

    A numeric vector of probabilities (values between 0 and 1 inclusive) for which to compute quantiles. Required and only used when type = "quantile".

    ...

    Currently unused arguments. Included for consistency with the generic predict method.

    Value

    The type of return value depends on the type argument:

    • If type = "density" or type = "cdf": A numeric vector of density or CDF values, respectively, corresponding to each value in newdata. The length matches the length of newdata.

    • If type = "quantile": A numeric vector of quantile values corresponding to each probability in p. The length matches the length of p.

    • If type = "response": A single numeric value representing the theoretical mean of the fitted distribution if newdata = NULL. If newdata was provided, a numeric vector repeating the theoretical mean, with length matching the length of newdata.

    Details

    This function acts as an interface to the underlying distribution functions corresponding to the fitted model's family (specified in object$family). It dynamically selects the appropriate density function (e.g., dgkw, dkw), CDF function (e.g., pgkw, pkw), quantile function (e.g., qgkw, qkw), or potentially a mean function (e.g., meangkw, meankw) based on the requested type and the fitted family.

    The function retrieves the estimated parameters using coef(object) and passes them along with newdata or p to the relevant underlying distribution function.

    Important: For this function to work correctly, the corresponding d, p, q (and mean if type = "response" is used, unless it's the standard Beta) functions for the specific family fitted (e.g., dkw, pkw, qkw for the "kw" family) must be available in the environment where predict.gkwfit is called (typically meaning they should be defined and exported by the same package).

    Input values in newdata must be strictly within the open interval (0, 1). Probabilities in p must be within the closed interval (0, 1).

    See also

    gkwfit, predict, and the specific distribution functions used (e.g., dgkw, pgkw, qgkw, dkw, pkw, qkw, etc.).

    Author

    Lopes, J. E.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Assume necessary functions like 'rkw', 'gkwfit',
# 'dkw', 'pkw', 'qkw', and 'meankw' (or equivalent logic) exist.

set.seed(123)
kw_data_sample <- rkw(100, alpha = 2.5, beta = 1.5)
fit_obj <- gkwfit(data = kw_data_sample, family = "kw", silent = TRUE)

# Example points for prediction
new_pts <- c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9)

# --- Predict Density ---
pred_d <- predict(fit_obj, newdata = new_pts, type = "density")
print(pred_d)
# plot(new_pts, pred_d, type = "l", main = "Predicted Density")

# --- Predict CDF ---
pred_p <- predict(fit_obj, newdata = new_pts, type = "cdf")
print(pred_p)
# plot(new_pts, pred_p, type = "l", main = "Predicted CDF")

# --- Predict Quantiles ---
probabilities <- c(0.01, 0.05, 0.5, 0.95, 0.99)
pred_q <- predict(fit_obj, p = probabilities, type = "quantile")
print(pred_q)

# --- Predict Mean Response ---
# Get the single theoretical mean value
pred_mean_single <- predict(fit_obj, type = "response")
print(pred_mean_single)

# Get the mean replicated for the length of newdata
pred_mean_vector <- predict(fit_obj, newdata = new_pts, type = "response")
print(pred_mean_vector)

# --- Example with a different family (assuming setup exists) ---
# set.seed(456)
# gkw_data <- rgkw(100, alpha=2, beta=3, gamma=1.5, delta=2.5, lambda=0.8)
# fit_gkw <- gkwfit(gkw_data, family="gkw", silent=TRUE)
# pred_gkw_cdf <- predict(fit_gkw, newdata = new_pts, type = "cdf")
# print(pred_gkw_cdf)
} # }
